nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: The Message
nodes.text: Your phone buzzes. A long message from your co-parent — sharp tone, quick accusations, and a few things that feel unfair.

choices.label: Pause before replying.
choices.text: You set the phone down and breathe for five seconds.

choices.label: Reply instantly with your frustration.
choices.text: You fire back: “This is not okay. Stop attacking me every time something happens.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: The Response
nodes.text: Their reply is fast and hot: “So now it’s MY fault again? You never listen. I’m done being the only one putting in effort.”

choices.label: Reflect the emotion, not the accusation.
choices.text: “I hear you’re overwhelmed. This sounds like a lot for you today.”

choices.label: Clarify your intention gently.
choices.text: “I’m not trying to blame you. Let’s slow this down a bit.”

choices.label: Counter the accusation.
choices.text: “Putting in effort? You know that’s not fair.”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Stabilizing or Spiraling
nodes.text: You sense the fragile moment where things can tilt either way — into clarity or chaos.

choices.label: State one shared goal.
choices.text: “Both of us want our child to feel safe. Let’s start from that.”

choices.label: Slow the tempo.
choices.text: “Can we pause for ten minutes? I want to give a thoughtful answer.”

choices.label: Point out contradictions in their message.
choices.text: “You say you’re the only one trying, but last week you asked me to cover extra days.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: Breaking Point or Breakthrough
nodes.text: Their next message is slower: “I’m tired. I just… feel like everything lands on me.”

choices.label: Acknowledge the emotion honestly.
choices.text: “I hear you. It *is* exhausting sometimes. Let’s figure out a way that feels fair.”

choices.label: Offer one concrete adjustment you can make.
choices.text: “Would it help if I handled school pickup twice next week?”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Scene
nodes.text: De-escalation isn’t magic — it’s a series of small choices that move storms toward calmer ground. Tonight, you practiced the art of slowing the fire instead of feeding it.
